records.title: World Sighting Records
records.subtitle: Extreme limits of crescent detection
records.danjonDescription: The minimum Sun-Moon elongation at which a crescent can physically exist. Below this limit, no part of the illuminated crescent is bright enough to detect.
records.whyAgeMisleading: Why Moon Age Alone Is Misleading
records.whyAgeMisleadingText: A 20-hour-old moon at apogee with poor ecliptic angle can be harder to see than a 16-hour-old moon at perigee with steep ecliptic. The critical parameters are {elongation}, {arcv} (arc of vision), {crescentWidth}, and atmospheric conditions — not age.

omeara.name: Stephen James O'Meara
omeara.description: Unbroken for 35+ years. O'Meara was the first to spot Halley's Comet on its 1985 return. The 7.7° elongation sits at the Danjon limit — the theoretical maximum for naked-eye visibility.

legault.name: Thierry Legault
legault.description: Captured at the precise instant of conjunction. This record can only be duplicated, never surpassed — you cannot photograph the Moon younger than age zero. Used near-infrared imaging with the Sun only 4.4° away.

stamm.name: Jim Stamm
stamm.description: ICOP record for youngest geocentric age through a telescope. The 6.0° elongation is below Odeh's empirical Danjon limit of 6.4° for optical aid.

records.sources: Sources: ICOP (astronomycenter.net), Sky & Telescope, Odeh (2006), Schaefer (1996), Legault, Bosscha Observatory.
